customer_name: Walt Disney World Parks and Resort U.S., Inc, DWS, Inc.
customer_addr:
1375 Buena Vista Drive/PO Box 10000
Lake Buena Vista, FL 32830

citations.narrative:
During a routine inspection, a review of records revealed the injury and death of two animals associated with handling
procedures. On October 20, 2023 during the catch up of chicks, an adult Greater flamingo with identification number
200171 fractured its right leg. The Greater flamingo was euthanized due to a poor prognosis for recovery. On November
19, 2023 an impala with identification number 150575 was being shifted from one enclosure to another. The impala
jumped, caught a horn on a fence, and broke its neck resulting in death. Handling of animals should be done as
expeditiously and carefully as possible in a manner that does not cause trauma.
To be correct from this day forward, June 26, 2024.

Records reviewed as part of a routine inspection documented an injury caused by another animal in the enclosure. On
December 28, 2022 an impala with identification number 090264 received a fracture of the left front limb during a
traumatic encounter with an okapi. The impala was euthanized on December 30, 2022 due to the extensive damage to
the elbow and a poor prognosis. Animals housed together should be compatible so that their interactions do not result in
trauma or death.
To be correct from this day forward, June 26, 2024.

Facility records dated October 15, 2023 documented the death of an Egyptian Goose with identification number 140645.
The deceased goose was found deceased in the corridor between the primary and perimeter fence. Necropsy records
state, “Near the same time we observed a bobcat with 2 mid-sized kittens emerging from the area. We think she may
have entered the savanna to catch him.” The report indicated the injuries were consistent with predation. Primary
enclosures must be constructed and maintained to restrict other animals from entering the enclosure.
To be correct from this day forward, June 26, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
Marla Renshaw, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER
Bryan Voetberg, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
2.131(b)(1)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
During a routine inspection, a review of records revealed the injury and death of two animals associated with handling 
procedures. On October 20, 2023 during the catch up of chicks, an adult Greater flamingo with identification number 
200171 fractured its right leg. The Greater flamingo was euthanized due to a poor prognosis for recovery. On November 
19, 2023 an impala with identification number 150575 was being shifted from one enclosure to another. The impala 
jumped, caught a horn on a fence, and broke its neck resulting in death. Handling of animals should be done as 
expeditiously and carefully as possible in a manner that does not cause trauma.  
 
To be correct from this day forward, June 26, 2024. 
3.133  Critical
   
Separation. 
Records reviewed as part of a routine inspection documented an injury caused by another animal in the enclosure. On 
December 28, 2022 an impala with identification number 090264 received a fracture of the left front limb during a 
traumatic encounter with an okapi. The impala was euthanized on December 30, 2022 due to the extensive damage to 
the elbow and a poor prognosis. Animals housed together should be compatible so that their interactions do not result in 
trauma or death. 
To be correct from this day forward, June 26, 2024. 
3.153(a)(1)(iv)  Critical
   
Primary enclosures. 
Facility records dated October 15, 2023 documented the death of an Egyptian Goose with identification number 140645. 
The deceased goose was found deceased in the corridor between the primary and perimeter fence. Necropsy records 
state, “Near the same time we observed a bobcat with 2 mid-sized kittens emerging from the area. We think she may 
have entered the savanna to catch him.” The report indicated the injuries were consistent with predation. Primary 
enclosures must be constructed and maintained to restrict other animals from entering the enclosure.  
To be correct from this day forward, June 26, 2024.

This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
Marla Renshaw, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER 
Bryan Voetberg, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
